newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy in full favour of EMU stability pact - Ciampi.
newsitem.headline: Italy in full favour of EMU stability pact - Ciampi.

text.p: Italy fully supports a proposed "stability pact" for countries joining Europe's planned economic and monetary union, Treasury Minister Carlo Azeglio Ciampi said on Friday.
He said in a speech inaugurating a special committee to oversse introduction of the euro in Italy that the government was "completely favourable" to the proposed pact.
Ciampi said Italy saw stability as resting on three pillars -- control of public spending, central bank autonomy and an incomes policy.
"Today, Italy can say that it has practically established all three," Ciampi said.
Countries will be assessed in early 1998 for EMU membership from January 1, 1999, on the basis of their 1997 economic performance.

Italy has drawn up a stringent budget for 1997 to try to meet the criteria, amid doubts whether it will do so or remain within the tight margins envisaged under the German-inspired stability pact to remain within EMU.
